Description: Egyptian Blue amuletic pendant in the form of a bunch of grapes; grapes indicated by raised squares, arranged in an ascending spiral; square suspension loop above, pierced centrally; material of very bright blue colour and medium hard texture, complete, encrusted with dirt.
Dimensions: Width: 0.80 centimetres (across flat top of grape bunch)
Curator's comments: Pendants in the shape of a bunch of grapes were very common in the New Kingdom though they were still produced later (Herrmann et al. 2010, 136, type 82; Persian period example: Herrmann 2006, 237, no. 478, pl. CIII; mould to produce bunch of grapes in glazed composition from the Ptolemaic quarter in Karnak: Masson forthcoming). They are linked with ideas of regeneration and kingship (Friedman 1998). Friedman, F. (ed.) 1998, Gifts of the Nile: Ancient Egyptian Faience, London. Herrmann, C. 2006, Ägyptische Amulette aus Palästina/Israel Band III (Orbis Biblicus et Orientalis, Series Archaeologica 24), 2006. Herrmann, C., Staubli, T., Berger-Lober, S., Keel, O., Schönbächler, G. 2010, 1001 Amulett : altägyptischer Zauber, monotheisierte Talismane, säkulare Magie, Bibel+Orient-Museum, Liebefeld, Stuttgart. Masson, A. forthcoming, Le quartier des prêtres sur la rive est du Lac Sacré à Karnak.
Bibliographic references: Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (OK.365) (phase 3)
